content.description:
Start as for 'Mr Gnarwhal'. Climb the crack, clip the first bolt and climb right onto thin face. 
Follow the bolts over crystals, edges, & pockets to a ledge & a set of rap rings.

Follows the bolt line above the alcove where the left leaning ramp and left leaning crack converge.
3 bolts. Rings at top.

climbs.name: Gnarcos
climbs.fa: Nick Taylor, September 14, 2019. Variation: Mike Vautour, September 14, 2019

content.description: Start at waters edge and traverse left, over the lake, through sidepulls & underclings to reach a bolt. Climb up a flake to a 2nd bolt. Pull crux move to gain left trending ramp. Follow the ramp left to reach an easy (and runout) slab that leads to the top of Mr. Gnarwhal. Finish at Mr. Gnarwhal tree anchor or traverse right on crimps to Gnarchetype rap rings. Variation:  Immediately after crux, traverse right to finish on Mr. Gnarwhal. Standing at the water's edge, Gnarcos climbs left over the lake to a bolt above some underclings. From here, the climb continues up past a second bolt to cracks and ledges above. Mixed: 2 bolts, standard rack. Tree anchor or rap rings.

Start on right leaning flake & cracks to the right of Gnarchetype.
Climb up to short crack and place protection before traversing left (runout crux with ground fall potential) to the first bolt of Gnarchetype. Climb the bolted line & finish at rap rings.

Starting foothold and crack may be wet after rain.

*Not recommended for TR because of large swing potential at start (crux) of the climb.*

Right and uphill of the alcove where left leaning ramp & crack converge. Starts on right leaning flake below a short, right leaning crack and dirty section above.
Finger sized gear protects (most of) the R-rated traverse. 3 bolts & ring anchor.

Climbs the prominent left leaning crack/right facing dihedral past small ledges to a tree anchor.
Alternately: Immediately below the grassy ledge, climb right onto face (5.9) and finish at 'Gnarchetype' rap rings.

Starts in the alcove where the prominent left leaning ramp and left leaning crack converge. The alcove is slightly right of the bolt line above.
Standard rack. Good pro. Easy stances & rests for beginners! Tree anchor.

Of the three main cliff sections, this face has the tallest, unbroken sections of climbing. The Gnar Wall is a less-than-vertical face featuring bolted slabbing, easy crack jamming, and one spicy 'don't get wet' start.

-South facing wall gets lots of sun & dries quickly

-Shady belay cuts down on wind exposure

-Secluded location feels isolated (No crowds!)

-Great views of Whale Cove Lake & Terence Bay

To be avoided during bug season!

Cliff top can be accessed at the right end of the wall via 3rd class trail (4th class if you don't walk far enough!) for TR setup and great views.

**Keep in mind: the tree anchor is directly above the water requiring careful set up & descent to KEEP ROPES DRY!**
